explanation:
Explanation of why each symbol is required for dead-code (MISRA) analysis of OS_MutSemGetInfo:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER
  - This macro enforces the NULL-pointer check on mut_prop. Its expansion/behavior (e.g. return, assert, no-op) determines whether the early pointer-check and any following initialization (memset) are actually executed or compile-time/elided — which affects whether those operations are dead.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById
  - The conditional that gates most of the function depends on this call's return. If this routine always fails/succeeds or has side-effects, then the branch body (record lookup, strncpy, Impl call, release) could be dead or live. You must know its possible return values and side-effects to judge dead code.

- OS_SUCCESS
  - The comparison against OS_SUCCESS controls the conditional. Its numeric value and semantics are required to reason about which branch is taken and whether the guarded block can ever execute.

- OS_object_token_t
  - The token type is passed to subsequent routines and to OS_ObjectIdRelease/OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl. Its representation/semantics (e.g. contains index or is a no-op type) affect whether token-related operations have observable effects.

- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE and OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL
  - These arguments to OS_ObjectIdGetById may alter its behavior (selection of object table, locking behavior). Knowing their definitions is necessary to determine if the call is meaningful or can be optimized away, which impacts dead-code analysis.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET
  - This macro/function retrieves the record from the global table. Its expansion may be a simple array access, an inlined index computation, or may call OS_ObjectIndexFromToken. It determines whether the record access lines are effective code or essentially no-ops.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken
  - Often used by table-access macros to convert token->index. If this is a pure computation or is inlined away, it may render parts of the record access redundant; its behavior/side-effects matter to determine dead code.

- OS_global_mutex_table
  - The table being indexed into. If the table is empty, statically removed, or mapped to a stub, then accesses to it (and subsequent copies from record) could be dead. Its existence/definition is required.

- OS_common_record_t
  - The record type defines name_entry and creator fields used by the function. Their presence, type, and alignment determine whether the strncpy and creator assignment are meaningful operations.

- OS_mut_sem_prop_t
  - The destination structure type (size of name field, creator field) is necessary to decide whether the prior memset and strncpy actually change observable state or are redundant initializations.

- OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl
  - This implementation call may duplicate or supersede the earlier copies/initialization (e.g. might fill mut_prop itself). If Impl always overwrites the same fields, earlier strncpy/memset could be dead. Knowing its behavior is essential.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease
  - Releasing the token may have observable side-effects (resource release, unlocking). If it is a no-op under some configurations, the release call might be dead; if it has side-effects, its removal would affect behavior. Its semantics are required.

In summary, to determine whether any operations in OS_MutSemGetInfo are dead (i.e. can be removed without changing program behaviour), you must know the semantics/expansions of the pointer-check macro, the object-id acquire/release pair (and their controlling constants), the table-access macro and underlying table/type definitions, and the Impl routine that may duplicate work. These symbols together determine whether the guarded block and the initial memset/strncpy/assignments are ever observable or redundant.
